A hackable text editor for the 21st Century

Teletype for Atom

Great things happen when developers work togetherâfrom teaching and sharing knowledge to building better software. Teletype for Atom makes collaborating on code just as easy as it is to code alone, right from your editor.

Share your workspace and edit code together in real time. To start collaborating, open Teletype in Atom and install the package.

Learn more

GitHub for Atom

A text editor is at the core of a developerâs toolbox, but it doesn't usually work alone. Work with Git and GitHub directly from Atom with the GitHub package.

Create new branches, stage and commit, push and pull, resolve merge conflicts, view pull requests and moreâall from within your editor. The GitHub package is already bundled with Atom, so you're ready to go!

Learn more

Everything you would expect

Cross-platform editing

Atom works across operating systems. Use it on OS X, Windows, or Linux.

Built-in package manager

Search for and install new packages or create your own right from Atom.

Smart autocompletion

Atom helps you write code faster with a smart and flexible autocomplete.

File system browser

Easily browse and open a single file, a whole project, or multiple projects in one window.

Multiple panes

Split your Atom interface into multiple panes to compare and edit code across files.

Find and replace

Find, preview, and replace text as you type in a file or across all your projects.

Make it your editor

Packages

Choose from thousands of open source packages that add new features and functionality to Atom, or build a package from scratch and publish it for everyone else to use.

Themes

Atom comes pre-installed with four UI and eight syntax themes in both dark and light colors. Can't find what you're looking for? Install themes created by the Atom community or create your own.

Customization

It's easy to customize and style Atom. Tweak the look and feel of your UI with CSS/Less, and add major features with HTML and JavaScript.


See how to set up Atom

Under the hood

Atom is a desktop application built with HTML, JavaScript, CSS, and Node.js integration. It runs on Electron, a framework for building cross platform apps using web technologies.

Open source

Atom is open source. Be part of the Atom community or help improve your favorite text editor.

Electron Blog

All the latest news from the Electron team and community.

  • Electron Governance
    ckerr sofianguy

    As Electron grows in popularity for desktop applications, the team working on it has also grown: we have more fulltime maintainers who work for different companies, live in different timezones, and have different interests. We're introducing a governance structure so we can keep growing smoothly.

    Read More 

  • Chromium FileReader Vulnerability Fix
    marshallofsound

    A High severity vulnerability has been discovered in Chrome which affects all software based on Chromium, including Electron.

    This vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2019-5786. You can read more about it in the Chrome Blog Post.

    Please note that Chrome has reports of this vulnerability being used in the wild so it is strongly recommended you upgrade Electron ASAP.

    Read More 

  • Discontinuing support for 32-bit Linux
    felixrieseberg

    The Electron team will discontinue support for 32-bit Linux (ia32 / i386) starting with Electron v4.0. The last version of Electron that supports 32-bit based installations of Linux is Electron v3.1, which will receive support releases until Electron v6 is released. Support for 64-bit based Linux and armv7l will continue unchanged.

    Read More 

  • BrowserView window.open() Vulnerability Fix
    ckerr

    A code vulnerability has been discovered that allows Node to be re-enabled in child windows.

    Read More 

  • Node.js Native Addons and Electron 5.0
    BinaryMuse

    If you're having trouble using a native Node.js addon with Electron 5.0, there's a chance it needs to be updated to work with the most recent version of V8.

    Read More 

  • Electron v5.0.0 Timeline
    sofianguy

    For the first time ever, Electron is excited to publicize our release schedule starting with v5.0.0. This is our first step in having a public, long-term timeline.

    Read More 

  • Electron 4.0.0
    BinaryMuse

    The Electron team is excited to announce that the stable release of Electron 4 is now available! You can install it from electronjs.org or from npm via npm install electron@latest. The release is packed with upgrades, fixes, and new features, and we can't wait to see what you build with them. Read more for details about this release, and please share any feedback you have as you explore!

    Read More 

  • SQLite Vulnerability Fix
    ckerr

    A remote code execution vulnerability, "Magellan," has been discovered affecting software based on SQLite or Chromium, including all versions of Electron.

    Read More 

  • Electron App Feedback Program
    sofianguy

    Electron is working on making its release cycles faster and more stable. To make that possible, we've started the App Feedback Program for large-scale Electron apps to test our beta releases and report app-specific issues to us. This helps us to prioritize work that will get applications upgraded to our next stable release sooner.

    Read More 

  • Electron 3.0.0
    codebytere

    The Electron team is excited to announce that the first stable release of Electron 3 is now available from electronjs.org and via npm install electron@latest! It's jam-packed with upgrades, fixes, and new features, and we can't wait to see what you build with them. Below are details about this release, and we welcome your feedback as you explore.

    Read More

    nornagon

  • WebPreferences Vulnerability Fix
    ckerr

    A remote code execution vulnerability has been discovered affecting apps with the ability to open nested child windows on Electron versions (3.0.0-beta.6, 2.0.7, 1.8.7, and 1.7.15). This vulnerability has been assigned the CVE identifier [CVE-2018-15685].

    Read More

  • Certificate Transparency Fix
    kevinsawicki

    Electron [1.4.12] contains an important patch that fixes an upstream Chrome issue where some Symantec, GeoTrust, and Thawte SSL/TLS certificates are incorrectly rejected 10 weeks from the build time of [libchromiumcontent], Electron's underlying Chrome library. There are no issues with the certificates used on the affected sites and replacing these certificates will not help.

  • Electron Internals: Weak References
    zcbenz

    As a language with garbage collection, JavaScript frees users from managing resources manually. But because Electron hosts this environment, it has to be very careful avoiding both memory and resources leaks.

    This post introduces the concept of weak references and how they are used to manage resources in Electron.

  • What's new in Electron 0.37
    zeke

    Electron 0.37 was recently released and included a major upgrade from Chrome 47 to Chrome 49 and also several new core APIs. This latest release brings in all the new features shipped in Chrome 48 and Chrome 49. This includes CSS custom properties, increased ES6 support, KeyboardEvent improvements, Promise improvements, and many other new features now available in your Electron app.

    Read More 

  • Use V8 and Chromium Features in Electron
    jlord

    Building an Electron application means you only need to create one codebase and design for one browser, which is pretty handy. But because Electron stays up to date with Node.js and Chromium as they release, you also get to make use of the great features they ship with. In some cases this eliminates dependencies you might have previously needed to include in a web app.

    Read More 

  • API Changes Coming in Electron 1.0
    zcbenz

    Since the beginning of Electron, starting way back when it used to be called Atom-Shell, we have been experimenting with providing a nice cross-platform JavaScript API for Chromium's content module and native GUI components. The APIs started very organically, and over time we have made several changes to improve the initial designs.

Build cross platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS

Releases

It's easier than you think

If you can build a website, you can build a desktop app. Electron is a framework for creating native applications with web technologies like JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. It takes care of the hard parts so you can focus on the core of your application.

Watch the video

Web Technologies

Electron uses Chromium and Node.js so you can build your app with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Open Source

Electron is an open source project maintained by GitHub and an active community of contributors.

Cross Platform

Compatible with Mac, Windows, and Linux, Electron apps build and run on three platforms.

The hard parts made easy

Automatic updates
Native menus & notifications
Crash reporting
Debugging & profiling
Windows installers

Get started

To get started with Electron, check out the resources below. Learn how to wrap your web app with Electron, access all the APIs, and generate installers.

Explore the Electron APIs

The Electron API Demos app interactively demonstrates the most important features of the Electron API. See what's possible with Electron with sample code and helpful tips for building your app.

Download from GitHub

View all releases on GitHub

Try more powerful experiments with Electron Fiddle

Electron Fiddle lets you create and play with small Electron experiments. It greets you with a quick-start template after opening â change a few things, choose the version of Electron you want to run it with, and play around. Then, save your Fiddle either as a GitHub Gist or to a local folder. Once pushed to GitHub, anyone can quickly try your Fiddle out by just entering it in the address bar.

Download from GitHub See more info

Spin up the Quick Start app to see Electron in action:

A minimal Electron app with helpful notations.

Or dive deeper and read the documentation.

Need Help?

Ask questions in the Discuss forum or our Slack channel. Follow @electronjs on Twitter for important announcements. Need to privately reach out? Email info@electronjs.org.

Apps built on Electron

With Electron, creating a desktop application for your company or idea is easy. Initially developed for GitHub's Atom editor, Electron has since been used to create applications by companies like Microsoft, Facebook, Slack, and Docker.

Build cross platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS

Releases

It's easier than you think

If you can build a website, you can build a desktop app. Electron is a framework for creating native applications with web technologies like JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. It takes care of the hard parts so you can focus on the core of your application.

Watch the video

Web Technologies

Electron uses Chromium and Node.js so you can build your app with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Open Source

Electron is an open source project maintained by GitHub and an active community of contributors.

Cross Platform

Compatible with Mac, Windows, and Linux, Electron apps build and run on three platforms.

The hard parts made easy

Automatic updates
Native menus & notifications
Crash reporting
Debugging & profiling
Windows installers

Get started

To get started with Electron, check out the resources below. Learn how to wrap your web app with Electron, access all the APIs, and generate installers.

Explore the Electron APIs

The Electron API Demos app interactively demonstrates the most important features of the Electron API. See what's possible with Electron with sample code and helpful tips for building your app.

Download from GitHub

View all releases on GitHub

Try more powerful experiments with Electron Fiddle

Electron Fiddle lets you create and play with small Electron experiments. It greets you with a quick-start template after opening â change a few things, choose the version of Electron you want to run it with, and play around. Then, save your Fiddle either as a GitHub Gist or to a local folder. Once pushed to GitHub, anyone can quickly try your Fiddle out by just entering it in the address bar.

Download from GitHub See more info

Spin up the Quick Start app to see Electron in action:

A minimal Electron app with helpful notations.

Or dive deeper and read the documentation.

Need Help?

Ask questions in the Discuss forum or our Slack channel. Follow @electronjs on Twitter for important announcements. Need to privately reach out? Email info@electronjs.org.

GitHub for Atom

The GitHub package brings Git and GitHub integration right inside your editor! Now you can switch or create branches, stage changes, commit, pull and push, resolve merge conflicts, view and checkout pull requests and more.

Visit the ð documentation to learn how to use all the features.

Install

The GitHub package comes already bundled with Atom, so there is nothing extra to install. ð

Feedback

We would love to hear your feedback. If you run into any problems, please open an issue. For contributions, take a look at the contribution guide.

Community packages

We also would like to point out all the amazing packages the Atom community has already created.

Give them a try to further improve your Git workflows. ð

Here just a few to check out:

  • git-plus
  • git-control
  • git-time-machine
  • git-history
  • git-blame
  • context-git
  • simple-git
  • split-diff

Build cross platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS

Releases

It's easier than you think

If you can build a website, you can build a desktop app. Electron is a framework for creating native applications with web technologies like JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. It takes care of the hard parts so you can focus on the core of your application.

Watch the video

Web Technologies

Electron uses Chromium and Node.js so you can build your app with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Open Source

Electron is an open source project maintained by GitHub and an active community of contributors.

Cross Platform

Compatible with Mac, Windows, and Linux, Electron apps build and run on three platforms.

The hard parts made easy

Automatic updates
Native menus & notifications
Crash reporting
Debugging & profiling
Windows installers

Get started

To get started with Electron, check out the resources below. Learn how to wrap your web app with Electron, access all the APIs, and generate installers.

Explore the Electron APIs

The Electron API Demos app interactively demonstrates the most important features of the Electron API. See what's possible with Electron with sample code and helpful tips for building your app.

Download from GitHub

View all releases on GitHub

Try more powerful experiments with Electron Fiddle

Electron Fiddle lets you create and play with small Electron experiments. It greets you with a quick-start template after opening â change a few things, choose the version of Electron you want to run it with, and play around. Then, save your Fiddle either as a GitHub Gist or to a local folder. Once pushed to GitHub, anyone can quickly try your Fiddle out by just entering it in the address bar.

Atom helper using more than 100% of CPU and causing macbook's fan to start

support
Zzzzzz 2019-04-03 19:08:32 UTC #1

Every time I open atom, the macbookâs fan starts shortly and when I check the activity monitor, the Atom Helper uses more than 100% of CPU. I think it is the reason that causes the fan to be working all the time.

After Googling, I used the atom --safe to start atom, and the %cpu is normal.

Does this mean that something is wrong with some of the packages that I installed? How to solve the problem? Does that mean that I cannot use normal mode any more?

Zzzzzz 2019-04-03 19:23:42 UTC #2

The problem is solved by deleting one of the .git folder under my username folder.

Etch, refs, props and classname

support
jkary 2019-04-02 00:01:00 UTC #1

Hello team!

I trying to wrap my head around UI elements using etch. It appears etch is a nice simple way to add to atom. Is there any web references you can point me to describing the refs, props, and classname?

I kinda get the concept but struggle with how the view and model (if separate classes) know about each other?

Take care
Jason

DamnedScholar 2019-04-02 05:50:41 UTC #2

The best documentation about using etch is the React documentation.

jkary:

I kinda get the concept but struggle with how the view and model (if separate classes) know about each other?

They know what you tell them. You donât have to have them be distinct classes, and in fact an etch component can handle all of its computation and data storage on its own if you arenât doing anything too complex. If you want to split the functionality into distinct entities, you will want to have your model/back-end side import your view object and run .update() on it as mentioned in the etch documentation whenever new data needs to be incorporated into the view.

jkary 2019-04-02 12:34:08 UTC #3

Thanks for the reply!

I guess Iâm so used to MVC, I assumed the same structure here. I am curious if you know of any examples which represent a good split between View and Model when things are complex? Iâve looked at a lot of examples of components that are created as foo.js and foo-view.js.

you will want to have your model/back-end side import your view object and run .update()

How does the model object know about the correct view instance? How does the view get kicked off? I am using:

  atom.workspace.addOpener(uri => {
   if (uri === 'atom://foobar/dock_item') {
     return new FooBarView();
   }
 })

in the model constructor but I donât think I have this quite right.

Take Care
Jason

DamnedScholar 2019-04-02 16:36:44 UTC #4
jkary:

I guess Iâm so used to MVC, I assumed the same structure here. I am curious if you know of any examples which represent a good split between View and Model when things are complex?

MVC isnât a part of JavaScript. Elixir is an example of a language where MVC is a guiding doctrine of the language, but JS was created before coders started having such strict separations of purpose and the language itself cares not at all. What this means is that MVC is what you make of it.

How does the model object know about the correct view instance?

If you want to go hard MVC, youâd have the controller know about both model and view, the model would be completely ignorant of the outside world (except with the ability to serialize() and deserialize()) and the view would only interact with anything else by spawning a UI. All business logic and API calls would be under the controller. Since you probably donât need the hardest of MVC, you might want to go with what most Atom package authors do and run with a controller-model that spawns, updates, and/or destroys the view when it needs to. For most Atom packages, this controller-model is the package itself (each package is exported as a class, so each package becomes an object in the JS universe inside Atom). So if you have a package and itâs not so complicated that you need to split it up, all you need to do is generate a view. Thatâs the relationship between the package-name.js and package-name-view.js files in most cases.

How does the view get kicked off?

When you use the URI method and register an opener, you will then activate your view using atom.workspace.open(), which returns a Promise that resolves into the view object returned by the callback inside addOpener (or a TextEditor by default). You can also pass an item (aka a compatible view object that returns an HTMLElement, which means you either want to pass it a DOM node or something with a DOM node at .element, which etch creates automatically) into open(). Thatâs not advertised in the documentation, but you can see how it works from checking out the code. atom.workspace.toggle() can also be used, as itâs shorthand for open() that also hides the object if it exists and is visible.

Youâve added the opener correctly. To open your view and pass the Promise into a place where your package can find it again, you want to do something like this:

atom.workspace.open('atom://foobar/dock_item').then(item => { this.view = item })

Release notes

v1.36.0-beta2 (2019-03-28)

  • Fixed an issue that caused Atom to open new (duplicate) windows for already-open projects (#18967)
  • Adjusted the default Jasmine test runner to allow you to activate packages listed in the APM_TEST_PACKAGES environment variable (#18984)

v1.36.0-beta1 (2019-03-13)

Fixed an issue that caused the File -> Open Folder menu option to display the Open File dialog (instead of the Open Folder dialog) (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18971)

v1.35.1 (2019-03-13)

Fixed an issue that caused the File -> Open Folder menu option to display the Open File dialog (instead of the Open Folder dialog) (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18971)

  • Upgrade to Electron 2.0.18 to address recent Chrome vulnerability
  • Fuzzy finder performance improvements
  • Fetch and display readonly inline comments in the GitHub pull request view

  • Fix restart behavior for "Restart and Install Update" on macOS
  • Fix Windows auto-update support detection
  • Don't watch TextEditors outside of the current project in Project Find

v1.33.0 (2018-11-28)

Notable Changes

  • Added built-in support for Rust using Tree-sitter (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18257)
  • Improved soft-wrapping behavior (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18287)
  • Added the ability to disable packages' snippets (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18261)
  • Moved the 'Undo Discard' button in the Git panel into a context menu (https://github.com/atom/github/pull/1702)
  • Added a commit list to the GitHub panel (https://github.com/atom/github/pull/1684)
  • Adding Git / GitHub icons to the status bar (https://github.com/atom/github/pull/1704)
  • Fixed an issue where Linux users were unable to push or fetch Git branches with the GitHub package on distributions with libcurl4 installed (#18201)
  • Fixed an issue where the Toggle Line Comments command created the wrong kinds of comments in files with multiple languages (atom/atom#18334)
  • Fixed multiple syntax highlighting issues and other issues involving the tree sitter parser:
  • Fixed missing syntax highlighting classes in several languages when using the new Tree-sitter parsing system
    • Ruby (https://github.com/atom/language-ruby/pull/244)
    • Go (https://github.com/atom/language-go/pull/158)
    • JavaScript (https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/611, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/612, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/614)
    • C (https://github.com/atom/language-c/pull/300)
    • Python (https://github.com/atom/language-python/pull/282)
  • Fixed missing syntax highlighting of CSS inside of JavaScript and HTML (https://github.com/atom/language-css/pull/156)
  • Fixed missing syntax highlighting of macro definitions in C code.
  • Fixed incorrect highlighting of raw byte strings in Rust code.
  • Fixed an issue where making rapid, large edits could cause invalid syntax highlighting (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18375)
  • Fixed an issue that caused a freeze when making certain edits to ERB files (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18342)
  • Fixed an issue where typing a '#' would spuriously insert curly braces in several languages (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18376)
  • Added the ability to fold several more types of statements in some languages (https://github.com/atom/language-go/pull/164, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/624)
  • Added several syntax highlighting classes that were accidentally removed in 1.32.0 (https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/620, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/623, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/622)
  • Fixed an issue that caused the API documentation to be omitted for some core Atom APIs (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18308)
  • Windows release artifacts signed with new certificate -- see details at https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.33.0-beta3

v1.33.0-beta3 (2018-11-20)

Notable changes

Fixed an issue that caused the API documentation to be omitted for some core Atom APIs (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18308)

Windows release artifacts signed with new certificate

This release uses a new code signing certificate for signing the Windows release artifacts. Because Windows Defender SmartScreen hasn't yet seen this certificate used in the wild, some users may see a warning when installing this release on Windows.

If you've downloaded a release artifact directly from https://github.com/atom/atom/releases or directly from https://atom.io and you encounter this warning, you can click "More Info" and then click "Run anyway" to proceed.

This warning should cease once Windows Defender SmartScreen gains trust for this new certificate over the coming days.

v1.33.0-beta2 (2018-11-09)

Notable Changes

  • Fixed an issue where making rapid, large edits could cause invalid syntax highlighting (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/18375)
  • Fixed an issue that caused a freeze when making certain edits to ERB files (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18342)
  • Fixed an issue where typing a '#' would spuriously insert curly braces in several languages (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18376)
  • Added the ability to fold several more types of statements in some languages (https://github.com/atom/language-go/pull/164, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/624)
  • Added several syntax highlighting classes that were accidentally removed in 1.32.0 (https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/620, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/623, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/622)

v1.33.0-beta1 (2018-10-31)

Notable Changes

  • Fixed an issue where Linux users were unable to push or fetch Git branches with the GitHub package on distributions with libcurl4 installed (#18201)
  • Fixed an issue where the Toggle Line Comments command created the wrong kinds of comments in files with multiple languages (atom/atom#18334)
  • Fixed missing syntax highlighting classes in several languages when using the new Tree-sitter parsing system
    • Ruby (https://github.com/atom/language-ruby/pull/244)
    • Go (https://github.com/atom/language-go/pull/158)
    • JavaScript (https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/611, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/612, https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/pull/614)
    • C (https://github.com/atom/language-c/pull/300)
    • Python (https://github.com/atom/language-python/pull/282)
  • Fixed missing syntax highlighting of CSS inside of JavaScript and HTML (https://github.com/atom/language-css/pull/156)
  • Fixed missing syntax highlighting of macro definitions in C code.
  • Fixed incorrect highlighting of raw byte strings in Rust code.

v1.31.0-beta0 (2018-08-28)

Notable Changes

  • Improved tree sitter highlighting for symbols based on scope and multiple selectors.
  • Tree Sitter grammars can now more easily detect file languages based on the first line of content.
  • Make hitting esc dismiss a notification instead of taking an action.
  • All Tree Sitter grammars now use their original TextMate scope names.
  • The JavaScript Tree Sitter grammar now highlights regular expressions in your code.
  • The Tree Sitter grammars for JavaScript and Ruby have been improved to more accurately highlight special variables and tokens.
  • Tree View has received many improvements such as the ability to add project folders using drag and drop from your file explorer, support for dragging multiple items to move them, and adding custom styles for ignored files and directories.
  • Git status for project folders is now reflected in the color of the project name.
  • Keyboard navigation with arrow keys in the Tree View now behaves more predictably with nested folders.
  • Make hideIgnoredNames and hideVcsIgnoredFiles play nicely together.
  • Add support for multiple, custom line number gutters.
  • Pull requests on the GitHub tab more closely match GitHub.com in styling.
  • Atom's TextEditor is now used to render code in Markdown previews and the Style Guide.
  • Usage metrics are now flowing through GitHub's internal analytics pipeline.
  • Migrated core packages about and one-light-ui into the Atom repository.
  • apm now uses Node 8.9.3 and npm 6.2.0.
  • Upgraded Electron to 2.0.7.
  • Fixed and issue where undoing an initial commit in a repo would throw an error.
  • Fixed missing READMEs on core package detail pages.
  • Fixed an issue where Atom's configuration file writes were not performed atomically.

v1.30.0 (2018-08-28)

Notable Changes

  • Updated to Electron 2.0.4
  • The GitHub tab now displays open pull requests for the repo you're working in and allows you to easily check out PR branches without leaving the editor.
  • The Git tab now renders emojis in recent commit messages.
  • Tree-Sitter now supports grammar injections which enable highlighting of JavaScript in HTML files and HTML inside of Ruby and JavaScript files.
  • A new Tree-Sitter grammar was added for language-ruby
  • New APIs for querying Tree-Sitter syntax nodes in a text buffer.
  • Added a <language scope name>:root-scope-used activation hook so that packages can be activated when a language is set as the root scope of a text editor.
  • Cmd+- now appears as the keybinding for window:decrease-font-size in the View menu on macOS.
  • Added a few new data points to our metrics package to better understand the impact of Atom's hackability.
  • Added Node.js, Chromium, and Electron version details to the About screen.
  • Added a new image-view.defaultBackgroundColor that configures the default background color when viewing images in Atom.
  • Fixed a regression in one-light-ui and one-dark-ui where text underlines appeared when hovering over clickable status bar elements.
  • Updated one-light-syntax and one-dark-syntax to provide better syntax coloring for embedded languages.
  • Fixed a crash that occurs when amending a co-authored commit.
  • Improved clickability of the "Push/Pull" status bar item.
  • Fixed issues in autocomplete-plus that [prevented some completions from being inserted] (https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/983) and degraded editor performance when editing long lines.
  • This fixes a bug where void tags (e.g. meta) fold weirdly when Tree-sitter is enabled in html.
  • Cursor movement across lines is now more predictable.
  • Hide tooltips when a user is typing.
  • Introduce new Atom APIs for observing Git repositories.
  • Don't clear built in CSS classes from TextEditor when calling updateClassList
  • Fixed an issue where panes were not calling onDidTerminatePendingState when destroyed.
  • Fixed spell check error on systems using a non-US locale as a default.

Creating a Package View in HTML/How to do it well

packages
WingofaGriffin 2019-03-26 22:24:20 UTC #1

Hi there,

I am working on a project in which we are building a package that opens up a new pane that will dynamically change based on the code in the original pane. The way that we currently have it working is that the pane is just a new Atom workspace and just translates it into plaintext.

In order to improve the user experience, I want to be able to make the interface a bit prettier, and as most of my experience lies in webdev, I thought it would be easy to use the fact that Atom is electron based to make the pane a page based on HTML that could be edited by the Javascript and less files that were already a part of the project. Unfortunately, after doing a good amount of searching, I canât find a way to do it in a simple way. The closest solution I see is Coffeescript, which I could make work but isnât ideal. If Coffeescript is the best option, do you have any advice on how to easily translate html work into it?

Thank you!

DamnedScholar 2019-03-27 00:28:13 UTC #2
WingofaGriffin:

The way that we currently have it working is that the pane is just a new Atom workspace and just translates it into plaintext.

The first thing I would recommend is to not use atom-workspace or any other custom tags in your packageâs element, if that is indeed what you mean by this sentence. atom-workspace is the top-level element of the DOM and thereâs generally just one. The only things I can think of at the moment that would cause conflicts are CSS (meh) and keybindings (possibly relevant), but itâs entirely possible for a package author or Atom dev to introduce code that looks for atom-workspace and does stuff to it, and thatâs not what you want. Stick with div unless you have a reason to go away from it. Now, if youâre not using the atom-workspace tag, ignore that whole paragraph and instead share your code with me so that I can see exactly what youâre doing.

As for the ways to build a new display, there are as many as there are roads to Rome. The only thing Atom requires is that your registered view returns a valid HTMLElement. If that is true, then Atom can easily plug it into the DOM and will handle all styling and manipulations. Since youâre seeing your output in Atom, I know that that part is taken care of, so we can look at ways to generate your HTMLElement. The traditional way is to use document.createElement(), but nobody wants to do that because it sucks. Since Atom manages the finer points of displaying your element, createElement() is actually useful for very simple things like displaying an image that you donât expect to change much. For views that update themselves when new information is received, you can use any of the variety of front-end frameworks available in the JavaScript world. Some of them might have assumptions that run counter to how Atom does things, so be careful, but all of them should work. I personally prefer etch, a small library designed for use in Atom based on the syntax and functionality of React components. The advantages of etch include not having anything except what you need to generate that HTMLElement and the fact that React takes layout instructions in the form of JSX, which looks like HTML and requires only minimal translation between the HTML layouts that we webby people construct in our heads on instinct and the code used to generate those layouts.

Once I see your code, I can fairly easily write up an etch component that takes you from where you are to where you can have your package set the variables that the component will draw from. Once you have one to play with, you should be able to see how it works and build on it with only a little reading about JSX.

WingofaGriffin 2019-03-27 01:13:44 UTC #3

Thank you so much for the help! Iâm afrai> atom.workspace.toggle

d Iâm a little behind you even haha. Just to make this clear, I am the person working on the design, and there are other people who have already created the backend functionality, so I am learning along right now.

The way we are toggling the pane is using the atom.workspace.toggle function. We are using getActiveTextEditor() to use that workspace as I spoke of above. There is currently no style whatsoever, so Iâd like to take a step back and be a bit more clear about how to move forward with this.

I have created a -view.js file where Iâve looked at the this.element stuff talked about in the flight manual here https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/package-word-count/ but it feels like adding the html elements as a bunch of children of the package element is bad for both my mental sanity and for how to do it well in the first place. It seems that you are telling me though that createElement is bad anyway so Iâll take a look at etch.

Hereâs the js snippet of the main thing https://jsfiddle.net/a5os4pv9/

Aerijo 2019-03-27 07:03:19 UTC #4

Regarding the CoffeeScript, there is no functional difference between CS, JS, and TS. They all turn into JS before being run.

WingofaGriffin 2019-03-27 16:13:35 UTC #5

Yes, I get that. Sorry for not making it clear. I just see in all examples of packages that do something similar to this using CS instead of pure JS, which seems to be a bit more similar to HTML, but am always looking to do it right, rather than just a bandaid solution!

DamnedScholar 2019-03-27 18:47:31 UTC #6

etch is really easy to get started with. All you need in your -view.js is this:

/** @jsx etch.dom */

const etch = require('etch')

class LiveProgrammingView {
  // Required: Define an ordinary constructor to initialize your component.
  constructor(props, children) {
    // perform custom initialization here...
    // then call `etch.initialize`:
    etch.initialize(this)
  }

  // Required: The `render` method returns a virtual DOM tree representing the
  // current state of the component. Etch will call `render` to build and update
  // the component's associated DOM element. Babel is instructed to call the
  // `etch.dom` helper in compiled JSX expressions by the `@jsx` pragma above.
  render() {
    return <div dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{__html: props.content} />
  }

  // Required: Update the component with new properties and children.
  update(props, children) {
    // perform custom update logic here...
    // then call `etch.update`, which is async and returns a promise
    return etch.update(this)
  }

  // Optional: Destroy the component. Async/await syntax is pretty but optional.
  async destroy() {
    // call etch.destroy to remove the element and destroy child components
    await etch.destroy(this)
    // then perform custom teardown logic here...
  }
}

export default LiveProgrammingView

Then you can import LiveProgrammingView just as you would any other JavaScript object and the HTMLElement is stored at LiveProgrammingView.element. You can change or destroy it with LiveProgrammingView.update() or LiveProgrammingView.destroy(), and with the configuration in the above snippet all you have to do is pass an object with an HTML literal like {content: '<pre>console.log("waddap homies")</pre>'}. The dangerouslySetInnerHTML property is explained here.

Now, for actually opening it, you should be able to do it with atom.workspace.toggle(LiveProgrammingView.element), but if not (or if you want to use the URI feature elsewhere in your package or even from outside Atom), you will want to register an opener (in which case your callback should check to make sure the URI string matches the string you want for your package, and then return the HTMLElement).

Caveat: Iâm at work and doing this from memory and documentation. Itâs possible that I forgot something, but Iâm pretty sure I didnât.

WingofaGriffin 2019-04-01 00:18:20 UTC #7

Wonderful! This seems like a pretty elegant solution that I am going to spend some time on.

Regarding the dangerouslySetInnerHTML tag, is there a best practice I should be following for the content tag? It probably is a case by case scenario, but my idea was to break it down into 3 main content sections, one for the title and info, one for a ul list, and one for a text input section. I just want to know if it makes more sense to do it all in one chunk, or separate it into smaller chunks for inputs, buttons, list items, etc.

Thank you so much!

DamnedScholar 2019-04-01 17:18:46 UTC #8

The most sense-making solution depends on the circumstances you find yourself with. The solution I presented is a default one that allows you as an HTML developer to build tags as youâre used to and pass them as a string to the React code. The JSX you see in the render() method looks like HTML and reads like it, but there are some differences in how the syntax works and it makes the most sense for you as the display person to build what you want in real HTML during the initial stage. I encourage you to think about which features of your view you might want to turn into components (anything where you might want the content to display dynamically, especially if it doesnât keep up with the rest of your display, and anything where you might want to add more instances of a tag programmatically, like with buttons), and when you have one of those, you can remove the code from the block of HTML you send and re-add it as a separate component in the JavaScript. This is super-easy once youâre comfortable with React, you just need to make sure that your JSX block always has one tag at the top level (thatâs a right-now rule, since Iâm not going to throw fragments at you and never use them myself), so if you want to throw some buttons in after your content block, you would reword it like this:

return <div>
  <div dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{__html: props.content} />
  <Button>Clickable Text</Button>
  <Button>Crash Atom</Button>
</div>

Convention dictates that components in React be title-capitalized, which is normal for classes across different languages, but especially relevant here because theyâre right next to lower-case HTML tags, so the capital letter plays an important role in identifying which elements are defined somewhere in your JavaScript and which use the built-in tag classes that come with React.

DamnedScholar 2019-04-02 17:11:57 UTC #3

Issues since the latest update that havenât received any maintainer responses would be the most decisive metric. The most broken packages have a bunch of those, because people submit issue requests and the owner has stopped paying attention to them.

    remote
} = require('electron');

    ipcRenderer

Sign in

What platforms does Atom run on?

Prebuilt versions of Atom are available for OS X 10.9 or later, Windows 7 or later, RedHat Linux, and Ubuntu Linux.

If you would like to build from source on Windows, Linux, or OS X, see the Atom README for more information.

Is Atom open source?

Yes. Atom is MIT licensed and the source is freely available from the atom/atom repository.

All core Atom packages provided by GitHub are also available under the MIT license.

How can I contribute to Atom?

You can contribute by creating a package that adds something awesome to Atom!

Also, if youâd like to contribute to the core editor, one of the bundled packages, or one of the libraries that power Atom, just go to github.com/atom.

You should also read the contributing guide before getting started.

Why does Atom collect usage data?

In the same way that aggregate usage information is important when developing a web application, we've found that it's just as important for desktop applications. By knowing which Atom features are being used the most, and how the editor is performing, we can focus our development efforts in the right place. For details on what data Atom is sending or to learn how to disable metrics gathering, visit https://github.com/atom/metrics.

d_l 2019-03-31 21:20:09 UTC #2

I take it that you are on Windows? I am on Ubuntu with Windows in dualboot when I (rarely) need it.

I suggest that you learn about SSH sessions between your development PC and your cloud services. There are some Atom packages you can install but I suggest that you start by installing PuTTY and becoming familiar with SSH sessions (setting aside Atom to start with).

Then you can create a number of SSH sessions in PuTTY GUI and you can then run such sessions by writing a bash script to be run through Atom by using an Atom package such as process-palette or script. You should explore the command line option of PuTTY.

If you prefer to work directly from Atom (bypassing PuTTY) you can try the package remote-sync.

But really there are many ways of connecting local to remote.

2902asdkl:

connect with a FTP

For future reference, this is the most important information you have to give us. (If you prefer SFTP, and especially if your hosting company does, most FTP clients and packages should support SFTP.)

For my personal FTP use, I have atom-commander which gives me a nice parallel view with my local files and the server, and I like how it naturally sits in the bottom dock because thatâs a more comfortable way for me to do edits when Iâm working on files on a remote server at the same time as files on my machine.

This part of it really hasnât changed at all since you got out. HTML files are still plain text interpreted by the browser and FTP is still exactly the same from a technical standpoint. The programs used to manipulate both have gotten more bells and whistles, but none of the core functionality is different.

2902asdkl:

One approach I would try (you do not explain if you are on Windows/Linux/Mac) is first install PuTTY

https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/latest.html

Then in Atom install remote-sync which connects to PuTTY.

I also suggest going further by looking at shinyapps and embedding the output in your electron app index.html.

ShadyThGod 2019-04-03 06:30:34 UTC #5

You can use something like node-fetch to fetch a remote file and then do something to that response.

For example, if the files you want to acquire are in a JSON format, you can do something like this:

const fetch = require('node-fetch');
...
app.on('ready', ()=>{
   ...
   fetch('https://path/to/json/file')
      .then(res => res.json()) //Converts the response to JSON
      .then(json => someFunctionToVisualizeJSON(json)) //Use some function to handle the converted JSON response
})

If you donât prefer fetch itself, you can use something like axios which is basically an improved version of the Fetch API.

I assume you have some sort of function or API to handle the files.

Aisbergg 2019-04-03 08:19:51 UTC #6

An implementation independent solution is to use a virtual filesystem to mount the directory on the remote server directly on your local machine. This way the remote files can be accessed like every other file on your local machine. This can be accomplished with SSHFS which is a network filesystem over SSH. It works on all platforms. Here is an article describing its use.

DamnedScholar 2019-04-03 15:22:22 UTC #7

This is doable, but anyone who tries it should be careful. Atom is a special case because it does a lot of stuff in the background, so it has difficulty with virtual filesystems due to all the things it pokes at while youâre using it. It ends up eating too many resources and potentially crashing. This problem can be avoided by being judicious and careful with how many activities your app does in the filesystem, and most Electron apps wonât have the same problems Atom does.

#####EOF##### Teletype for Atom

Collaborate in real time in Atom

Teletype(beta) for Atom lets developers share their workspace with team members and collaborate on code in real time.

Get started

Code better, together

Working on code together in real time is valuable for knowledge sharing and producing quality software. The Teletype package for Atom aspires to make it as easy for developers to code together as it is for them to code alone.

Teletype introduces the concept of real-time "portals" for sharing workspaces. When a host opens a portal, their active tab becomes a shared workspace. There, invited collaborators can join in and make edits in real time. As the host moves between files, collaborators follow along with the active tab automatically.

How code gets shared

Each portal comes to life in two steps:

  1. First you connect to our servers to see who is collaborating. ð   Hi there.

  2. After that, collaborators share code directly with each other (peer-to-peer).

There's no centralized server to spy on your keystrokes, and Teletype uses WebRTC to encrypt all communication between collaborators. What happens in the portal stays in the portal.

Getting started

1. Install Atom

Download and install Atom. It's free, open source, and cross-platform. You can use it on Windows, macOS, or Linux.

2. Install Teletype for Atom

Install the teletype package to start collaborating today. If you need help, take a look at how to install Atom packages.

Share a portal

Click the icon in the Atom status bar, and flip the switch to start sharing a portal to your workspace. Then invite people to join your portal by sending them your portal URL.

Join a portal

Once someone has provided you with a link to their portal, simply follow the link to join the portal. The portal opens and all collaborators can edit together in real time.

Feedback

We welcome your feedback on this beta release. If you run into any problems, please open an issue or take a look at the contribution guide and start contributing.

Error Code "The system can not find the file specified"

support
AJCastle 2019-04-01 18:48:47 UTC #1

I am running windows 10 and downloaded atom.io a few days ago. Thanks

DamnedScholar 2019-04-02 05:34:50 UTC #2

Since Atom canât run any code, you must be using a package. If you identify the package, we can help you figure out why this is happening. It would also be useful for you to post a screenshot of Atom open to the file youâre trying to run.

AJCastle 2019-04-02 23:13:18 UTC #3

I have script downloaded for running code. Heres a screen shot of what is happening.

AtomioHelp.PNG3840Ã2160 302 KB

DamnedScholar 2019-04-03 15:13:16 UTC #4

First, the script package is unable to handle spaces in the filename. This is a flaw in how the package was written and your choices (to get your issue fixed immediately) are to move the file to a different location that is outside of your user folder or download a different package. I fancy process-palette for all command line activities, but there are a variety of packages for this purpose and you should find the one that best meets your needs.

Second, you should reconsider storing your code files inside .atom/. .atom/ is for storing local configuration files and some of the things Atom needs to run. The best way to organize code files is to keep them with other personal documents in a folder that doesnât have the potential of needing to be removed and replaced if something happens to your settings or the cache gets corrupted. This is not common, but if you ran into an issue with .atom/ and something happened to it, that could potentially cause problems for your code files or force you to copy them all out before you can fix the problem.

Loading multiple HTML files

electron
hcphoon01 2019-04-02 09:36:59 UTC #1

Hello,

How can I go about loading multiple HTML files, for example a base html file containing references to scripts, a nav html file containing a nav bar, and then the actual html file for the specific page?

Thanks

d_l 2019-04-02 13:44:02 UTC #2

I can only set out the several methods I am trying out for my own composition needs â¦

  • snippets
  • modular-snippets
  • emmet
  • php include
  • pandoc to concatenate files

Pandoc is a simple way of joining file fragments through command line, requiring pandoc to be installed and on $PATH. HTML and markdown fragments can be joined. If joined markdown is used then markdown-preview-enhanced package is recommended.

hcphoon01 2019-04-02 13:48:17 UTC #3

So what should I actually use?

d_l 2019-04-02 14:51:37 UTC #4

These are the rules I have learned by trial and error (still evolving). Follow these as separate experiments.

Start with snippets which is built into Atom core.
Run apm list to see all your packages.

See Edit > Snippets â¦ and add your own snippets as fragments of HTML documents.

If you wish to have different classes of snippets for multiple, different projects, explore modular-snippets.

If you are using PHP you can use PHP snippets. Then you will need php-server to preview PHP rendered in browser.

If you are writing large blocks of text to insert as document fragments you might use Markdown and pass through Pandoc to compose HTML (or other) documents.

If you want to apply variables to the inserted elements, explore atom-emmet but then you need to consider clashes between snippets and emmet. Then you might need emmet-snippets-compatibility package.

It is a case of trial and error and much depends on the nature of the end content to be created (composed).

I am currently importing js frameworks using the above approach.

hcphoon01 2019-04-02 16:07:32 UTC #5

Not sure how any of this helps me on the electron framework

d_l 2019-04-02 16:30:17 UTC #6

Well Iâm using them for electron server and client dev.

DamnedScholar 2019-04-02 16:48:44 UTC #7
hcphoon01:

for example a base html file containing references to scripts, a nav html file containing a nav bar, and then the actual html file for the specific page?

You want load a base HTML file that has access to JavaScript that builds the rest for you, or you want to add a build step to your application that compiles all of your source files into the final files that the user views. (In general, you should go for the first one, because Electron is best suited for single-page applications where you donât worry about routing to specific HTML pages but have your JS build everything on the spot.) There are as many ways to do this as there are JavaScript frameworks in the wild. The one I know best right now is React, so I can provide specific guidance if you want to get into that.

hcphoon01 2019-04-02 17:05:06 UTC #8

I think the react route is the way Iâm wanting to go, Iâve come from using Laravel and in that its quite easy to make a file just for the navbar for example and for that to be included in the content files, I suppose that can be done in react

DamnedScholar 2019-04-02 17:26:19 UTC #9

The main difference between React and PHP is that youâre not going to have separate markup files. Instead, youâll have one HTML file that includes your JS and an empty div with a unique ID*. The React script will take that div and insert into it anything you tell it to. You then build a set of components as individual JavaScript classes or functions and compose them in JSX (which looks a whole lot like HTML and only has some minor syntax differences). Hereâs the entry point to the documentation.

* The HTML file I provided as an example doesnât link to my JavaScript, but thatâs because this specific project uses Webpack and Webpack adds in the script tag when it compiles everything. The one I linked to is the only React project I have on my GitHub at the moment. Based on your Laravel experience, you might find it comfortable to use the same building block I did, Atomic React, which will scaffold out your application and give you well-defined places to put each of your components and assets.

How to show changed files in different color in tree-view

support
cbcoutinho 2016-06-29 19:49:38 UTC #1

I have been seeing a number of screen shots of users with tree-views showing different colors for updated/unsaved files. Is this default behavior in the tree-view package, or is it provided elsewhere?

I was unable to find it in the settings, but itâs possible i missed it.

leedohm 2016-06-29 19:52:01 UTC #2

It is default behavior for the Tree View if you are working with a Git repository and the .git directory is in the root of the project. In other words, if you have a structure like /home/projects/my-awesome-project/sub-dir where my-awesome-project is the root of a Git repository, you have to open my-awesome-project in Atom â¦ not projects or sub-dir.

cbcoutinho 2016-06-29 20:16:06 UTC #3

Howdy, thanks for the info. I had opened the file from a directory a few levels above the repo - makes sense.

Thanks again!

trusktr 2019-04-03 17:07:49 UTC #4

Hello @leedohm, how do we turn off the feature? Or more specifically, how to we turn off color, but leave grayed-out ignored files grayed-out?

DamnedScholar 2019-04-03 17:21:26 UTC #5

I donât know of a way to disable the adding of the CSS classes, but you can restyle them. The selectors are .list-tree li.list-nested-item.status-added > .list-item and .list-tree li.list-nested-item.status-modified > .list-item, or in Less:

.list-tree li.list-nested-item {
  &.status-added, &.status-modified {
    > .list-item {
        color: blue;
    }
  }
}
